affiliations.name: NSF National Center for Atmospheric Research

children.value: In this tutorial, you’ll learn about:

children.label: In this tutorial, you’ll learn about:

children.value: The differences and similarities between UXarray’s and Xarray’s plotting routines

For users coming from an Xarray background, much of UXarray’s design is familiar. This notebook showcases an example of transitioning a visualization of a structured grid using Xarray into a visualization of an unstructured grid using UXarray.

import cartopy.crs as ccrs
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import uxarray as ux
import xarray as xr

children.value: We use two variations of the
grid for this example. One of them is the original unstructured cube sphere, with the other being a remapped structured version.

base_path = "../../meshfiles/"
ds_path = base_path + "outCSne30.structured.nc"
xrds = xr.open_dataset(ds_path)
xrds

text/plain.content:
<xarray.Dataset> Size: 30kB
Dimensions:  (lat: 45, lon: 80)
Coordinates:
  * lat      (lat) int64 360B -90 -86 -82 -78 -74 -70 -66 ... 66 70 74 78 82 86
  * lon      (lon) float64 640B -180.0 -175.5 -171.0 ... 166.5 171.0 175.5
Data variables:
    psi      (lat, lon) float64 29kB ...

children.value:
base_path = "../../meshfiles/"
grid_filename = base_path + "outCSne30.grid.ug"
data_filename = base_path + "outCSne30.data.nc"

uxds = ux.open_dataset(grid_filename, data_filename)
uxds

children.label: Using hvPlot to combine UXarray & Xarray Plots

children.value: , we can visualize Xarray and UXarray plots together by using
To learn more about hvPlot and Xarray, please refer to the

import holoviews as hv
import hvplot.xarray

hv.extension("bokeh")

children.value:
(
    xrds.hvplot(cmap="inferno", title="Xarray with hvPlot", width=800, height=400)
    + uxds["psi"].plot(
        cmap="inferno",
        title="UXarray Plot",
        width=800,
        height=400,
        periodic_elements="split",
    )
).cols(1)
